rename.to: [DOC] documentation & developer instructions (Windows experience) fixing umbrella issue

body: I will pick up the 2nd task -  completing and re-organizing the developer guide (currently mostly empty!) and the "how to contribute" page.

Great (as discussed) - @amrith-shell, it would be nice if you could kindly outline what in your opinion should go where, i.e., a sketch of end state. Happy to help with that tomorrow, although I assume you might already have better ideas since you worked through this in the user journey.
@jasonlines has a version of this too, good to compare notes

yep, went through the pain of getting it up and running on windows last week so uninstalled everything to do it again yesterday from first principles and document it. I've taken screenshots throughout and the plan is to put it together in a doc/guide - happy to put it together as a notebook or similar initially and go from there?
great! Let's do this together then
I have some instructions written up in markdown that I was able to use for a successful install on a new windows pc. It will be interesting to see if we have the same path.
ok great, sounds good. I'll aim to get mine into a markdown by tomorrow lunchtime (hopefully the close of play today though) and we can compare notes before going from there

issue.title: Windows installation guide for sktime development with Anaconda and PyCharm

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
A walk-through guide for setting up sktime for development with PyCharm and Anaconda. Also includes examples with pytest and pre-commit within PyCharm


#### Reference Issues/PRs
Contributes to part 2 of #1635 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Documented example of installing sktime on Windows, specifically using PyCharm and Anaconda with extensive screenshots to guide new users. While PyCharm is used as the IDE, instructions are separated out so that just the environment instructions can be followed (i.e. Section 2) without need for PyCharm, if preferred.  

The notebook is in examples/windows_installation.ipynb and the other files that have been added are screenshots that are used within the notebook. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

No code introduced has been introduced but I'm not sure if this is the correct place for it - it may be better in the \docs but I'm not sure how best to include the images and have used a notebook as a first pass. Also, please comment on whether the instructions are informative or if you have suggestions for any changes

#### Any other comments?

body: It took longer than planned but please see #1640 for my first pass at this

In terms of the 2nd task of re-organizing the documentation/developer guide, I took the approach of categorizing various sections of the documentation and created a hierarchy/ decision tree of the documentation structure. Please see my initial draft.

If you have any comments or suggestions please do let  me know.

![documentation design](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83223497/143680784-ca0e95dc-b9d6-4520-b2bd-60cc7abbccd8.png)

Thanks!I think idea-wise this makes a lot of sense, excellent!

Few comments:
* you forgot "get started", that's perhaps the most important entry point! This should also link to "installation" directly. The "installation" page, in my opinion, should contain workflows for release install, development version install, and developer/build install (these are very similar).
* moving stuff from "contributing" to the developer guide makes sense. However I'd also link directly from "contributing" to the "developer guide", and possibly individual sub-sections.
* I think "code of conduct" should appear primarily under "get involved", and linked in "contributing" too. Any interaction with the project should be subject to the CoC.
* would "governance" make more sense under "get involved"?

PS: with my day job hat on (i.e., @fkiraly-shell), the project item scope is ensuring that the Windows install related documentation is unambiguous. I.e., this can imply moving some material around, but we'd focus on getting the install instructions "de-duplicated" and the structure of contributing/development cleaned up primarily.

Updated documentation structure based on feedback 
![documentation design](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83223497/144220608-e59d41af-2072-4852-909b-d6807f87d229.png)

[Developer install sktime instructions.md](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/files/7633142/Developer.install.sktime.instructions.md)

Here are my instructions written in markdown for windows developer installation. These should take you from start to finish (tested on my home computer). It remains to integrate them into the current installation instructions. I will set up a PR for updating the visual studio documentation and properly setting up a conda environment. 

Once the restructuring has been implemented, a small rework of the installation instructions could be done. In particular, I have realised a lot of the information that I needed to fix the problems I had was on the page, but it is in different places. (e.g. fbprophet fix)

issue.title: Update windows install doc

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Updated the Windows build requirements and installation instructions to be up to date with latest Visual Studio code. Also updated instructions to ensure that the conda environment set up works from a fresh install to get an editable developer version.

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Contributes to part 1 of #1635 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
It updates the Windows section of the development installation guide. Specifically it updates the instructions for installing Visual Studio Code for 2022 and clearly shows which components are needed. It also updates the sequence of commands to obtain a working conda environment for sktime development stating how to resolve some common dependency issues as well as some ways that users can check that their installation has worked.


#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
The clarity of the new instructions. Is there anything else that should be addressed? Does the image I've added in the Build Tools for Visual Studio Tools section load correctly?

I have kept as much of the old instructions as I could, for example attempting to install via `python setup.py install` outside an environment, however I couldn't get this to work myself. Should I remove this and only have instructions for an anaconda environment? Thus introducing a new requirement for windows installation, or keep it as is, as it may work for some people.
 
#### Any other _comments?_
I plan to make further changes to the order of the installation instructions once the restructuring in #1635 part 2 has taken place. This PR is simply to update the windows instructions so that they should work.

issue.title: [DOC] reformatted the documentation structure

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs

This is related to issue #1635 , also related #1448 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This pull request addresses the reformatting of the documentation structure to follow the following hierarchical structure  
![documentation design](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83223497/144827736-721f12cc-9bab-403e-b6a8-251752ec42d4.png)


#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No new dependency introduced.


#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
- [ ] Review the documentation structure
- [ ] Ensure that text has not been deleted

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
